R. Levii saith, Because the ten command- ments [of the decalogue] are comprehended therein.'' And he shews further how they are comprehended, saving only (which is very observable) the second commandment. After- ward indeed they confess, “It was very fitting they should every day repeat the very decalogue itself ; but they did not repeat it, lest the heretics should say, that only those com- mandments were given to Moses on Mount Sinai.” However, they did repeat those passages wherein they supposed the decalogue was sumnied up.

XVhethen therefore, this lawyer of ours understood the words of our Saviour as having respect to that usage of re- peating their phylacteries; or whether he of his own accord, and according to his own opinion, would be giving the whole sum of the decalogue, he shews himself rather a textual than a. traditional doctor, although the word νομικὸς, lawyer, seems to point out the latter rather.
